descriptionSet.description: In this poster an Indian woman is enjoying a tea break after/before playing tennis. She is dressed in a sari and wearing tennis shoes and gold jewellery. She holds a steaming cup of tea and saucer in her hand and the tennis racquet rests on her lap and a tennis ball lies by the chair. There is also a plate of biscuits on a low table beside her chair. In the background there are some trees and a well-maintained hedge with an open white gate.

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art
Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

titleSet.title: A woman having a cup of tea

hra:item.hra:value: text-en: TCM [publisher's signet]

description-en: In this poster an Indian woman is enjoying a tea break after/before playing tennis. She is dressed in a sari and wearing tennis shoes and gold jewellery. She holds a steaming cup of tea and saucer in her hand and the tennis racquet rests on her lap and a tennis ball lies by the chair. There is also a plate of biscuits on a low table beside her chair. In the background there are some trees and a well-maintained hedge with an open white gate. (sp)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Jewellery, shoes, the tennis racket and the bodily posture suggest that the woman comes from a wealthy and western educated background. The backdrop could even be situated in Britain, or another western country (not a hill station because there are no hills). This is also evidenced from the colonial furniture and the fact that tennis was not very common during that period for an Indian women to play as a leisure activity.() (cb/sp)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Yet this imperial infusion, steeped in porcelain "china" pots, accompanied by pitchers of warm milk and spoonfuls of sugar, had already begun to be savored by the bhadralok ("well bred") residents of Calcutta. This taste begins to be attested to in Bangla literature and advertising after ca. 1880, but it was initially restricted to a comparatively small Anglophile elite. Indeed, much pre-Independence tea advertising (including the majority of the relevant images in the Paul Collection) suggests such a target audience, emphasizing comfortable bourgeois domesticity, modernity in costume and furnishings (e.g., the sari-clad tennis player of this poster, with her Westernized blouse and smart white sneakers). (Philip Lutgendorf) (gs)
